title: Schoolboy cancer sufferer left in squalor by cowboy builders has home of his dreams after Good Samaritans read of his plight in The Sun
text:
Opinion 'WE HAD TO HELP' Schoolboy cancer sufferer left in squalor by cowboy builders has home of his dreams after Good Samaritans read of his plight in The Sun 
Kind-hearted team from Mercer Group begin work on patching up Hashim Al-Alawi's home for free By DEAN WILKINS Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments A SCHOOLBOY cancer sufferer left in squalor by cowboy builders will finally have the home of his dreams after Good Samaritans read about his family’s plight in The Sun. Cancer Victim Hashim give the thumbs-up as work begins to fix home wrecked by cowboy builders News Group Newspapers Ltd Hashim lends a hand as builders from Mercer Group get down to work News Group Newspapers Ltd Building firm boss Dave Mercer told how he sprang into action after reading of Hashim’s plight in The Sun 
And now a team of do-gooders have arrived to finish the work for free. 
Led by builders from the Mercer Group, a team of six started fixing Hashim’s house of horrors, who has been battling a brain tumour for three years. 
And they expect to have completed the renovation in just three weeks – putting an end to the family’s 18 months of hell. 
Dave Mercer, 51, director of the firm from Bolton, Greater Manchester, told The Sun: “I read The Sun’s story and we immediately wanted to extend our help and expertise to the family and get their home back to a suitable condition for their sick son. 
“I told my wife I had to do something and couldn’t just sit there, so I went round to see Hashim and his family. RELATED STORIES CANCER TEEN'S BUILDER MISERY Teen cancer victim living in house with no heating and leaking roof after builders 'drank £11k of parents' money in the pub' FUSSY BEGGAR Homeless man refuses Good Samaritan’s offer of a new home – because it's not pet-friendly enough for his cat HEROIC EFFORT Heartwarming moment Good Samaritans pull elderly man from overturned car after he flipped it in horrifying crash RIGHT MOVE Good Samaritan builds young homeless couple their own £350 mobile house with insulation, fire alarm and a lock AMAZING GESTURE Heartwarming footage shows barefoot homeless woman given new trainers on bus by Good Samaritan 
“His dad broke down in tears on my shoulder as he showed me round. He felt ashamed for what had happened to them. He felt he’d let his family down. 
“I told them not to worry and that everything will be alright – and started planning the big fix. 
“All the work will be done free of charge. This story has touched the hearts of a lot of people. 
“I’ve had offers of help from all over the UK – from the south coast to East Anglia – there are a lot of good tradesman in this country who would not stand by and let something like this happen. News Group Newspapers Ltd The team from Mercer Group expect to finish renovations in three weeks – putting an end to the family’s 18 months of hell News Group Newspapers Ltd Repairs are well under way at Hashim’s home in Rochdale that was left in a virtually uninhabitable condition News Group Newspapers Ltd 10 Hashim was left in a house with no heating, exposed wiring and a leaking roof after his family were allegedly ripped off by builders 
“We are more than happy to get involved and do what we can for the family and their son.” 
We told how Danny Kearney, 29, Lee Ray, 44, and a mate were hired by Hashim’s father Al-Habib, 55, and allegedly paid £4,000 up front and £7,735 for materials before vanishing within weeks. 
Al-Habib, of Rochdale, Greater Manchester, claims when he rang to ask for the cash he was told: “We drank it in the pub.” 
The Mercer Group are raising awareness for The Joshua Wilson Brain Tumour Charity. 
The group, who have been supporting the Al-Alawi family throughout Hasim’s treatment, was set up in memory of Joshua Wilson, who battled terminal cancer for 11 years before passing away in 2014 aged just 14. News Group Newspapers Ltd Hashim’s father Al-Habib, 55, and mum Fahima, 49, say they are £11,700 out of pocket over renovations News Group Newspapers Ltd 10 Dad Al-Habib said the builders took £4k up front and an additional £7k for materials before vanishing and refusing to give the cash back 
Joshua’s mum Dawn Fidler, who founded the charity, told The Sun: “Helping Hashim’s family find a fix for their home has been one of most complex cases, they have been left to live in crisis and we were determined to help them. 
“I can’t say a big enough thank you to Dave Mercer and his team and suppliers for all their time and help making Hashim’s family home safe again. 
“We are so proud, it’s incredible to be able to help in my amazing boy’s legacy.” News Group Newspapers Ltd The botched job left the Al-Alawis with exposed wiring hanging from the ceiling News Group Newspapers Ltd 10 The family is now too poor to sue the builders for the damage as they cannot afford the legal costs 
When confronted by The Sun, Kearney disputed the sum involved, saying: “I didn’t take cash up front. We agreed he would be pay me £250 a week and after a week asked me to do it for £150. I told him I wouldn’t do the work for that.” 
Ray added: “We wouldn’t have said we drank away the money because we don’t drink.” 
A Gofoundme page set up to help raise money for the family has already surpassed their goal of £2,000.
